snippet: In 2004, there was little about the economic climate that would explain why a housing peak should be coming soon. But something else, hard to discern, was driving things.
abstract: Robert J Shiller Economic View contends the housing market boom and bust was a dual social epidemic of positive thinking leading to high expectations, followed by negative thinking that discouraged buying or spending; admits that certainly there were other factors behind the boom and bust, but many of them were arguably driven by this same social epidemic.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, there was little about the economic climate that would explain why a housing peak should be coming soon. But something else, hard to discern, was driving things.
